from IPython.core.display import Image Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png') print("Welcome to Academic!") Welcome to Academic! Install Python and JupyterLab Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.
Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.
Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).
In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:
--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... --- Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post‚Äôs folder.
For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.
Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=. Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

content:
I work on the frontier of theoretical particle physics and cosmology. I‚Äôm in particular interested in the origin of matter-antimatter asymmetry, as well as other cosmological and experimental probes of interesting physics. This page shows research directions that I‚Äôm currently working on. Other interesting topics may also catch my eye in the future.
Parity-symmetric model The smallness of the strong CP phase in the Standard Model has been a puzzle for decades, called ‚Äúthe strong CP problem‚Äù. One elegant solution is to impose a parity symmetry $L\leftrightarrow R$ and extend the SM gauge group as $SU(3)_c \times SU(2)_L \times SU(2)_R\times U(1)_X$. This symmetry can forbid the strong-CP phase at least at tree-level, and provide a high-scale, electroweak-like phase transition $SU(2)_R \times U(1)_X \rightarrow U(1)_Y$.
This extension of the standard model provides possibility to solve other problems together. For example, the new phase transition may open a window to generate the baryon asymmetry in a similar mannor of the well-known electroweak baryogenesis, see this paper for details. It can also provide good dark matter candidiates, if any of the new fermions are neutral and stable.
Besides the work for baryogenesis mentioned above, I‚Äôm currently working on dark matter signatures, and also exploring more possibility to produce interesting signals.
Electroweak phase transition and electroweak baryogenesis The electroweak phase transition, if strong first order, offers out-of-thermal-equilibrium condition required for successful baryogenesis. However, the Higgs quartic coupling is too strong so that the electroweak phase transition in the SM is a smooth crossover. Extension is required to enhance the phase transition. Furthermore, interesting thermodynamics are involved once we talk about the details of phase transition and CP-violating interactions which is another necessary piece for the baryon asymmetry.
I work on model buildings to extend the phase transition, and I spend plenty of time exploring interesting thermodynamics.
Probes light particles in experiments Besides heavy BSM particles, potential light particles are also strongly motivated and waiting to be probed. One famous example is the dark mediator. It‚Äôs well known that dark matter is an existing puzzle, and they are part of a ‚Äúdark sector‚Äù in many models. The dark mediator is the only way that dark sector talks with the SM particles, and thus dark mediator is strongly motivated. The parameter space are in wide range, but typically they are not too heavy (far below EW scale). Among them, some light and weakly interacting mediators are particularly interesting for their potential to solve the muon $g-2$ puzzle. Those particles are typically long-lived, and give specific experimental signatures such as displaced vertex.
I study on possible new searches on this type of long-lived mediators. For example, dark photon and dark scalar.
title: Research
